We are in the South Lantau foot hills, 20 min walk to Mui Wo beaches and ferry pier. 10 min by bike.
Our village is accessible by concrete village path suitable for bikes and tricycles.
All shops and transport 10 minutes from the house. Then a gorgeous cross harbour 30 min fast ferry ride lands you smack in Central HK!
Your cowshed is surrounded by banana plantations and farmer's fields. We are in a village but are completely private from the other houses.
In the neighbourhood we have temples, organic farms, waterfalls, rivers, hiking trails, mountains, sandy beaches, restaurants, a market, shops, sports centre, library, playgrounds, public basketball and tennis courts, bookstores, bars and cafes. Mui Wo Village and the rest of South Lantau is a wonderful place to explore.
The cowshed itself is right in the middle of amazing hiking paths. One minute from the door step is a beautiful rocky river to explore.
So lucky! Best of city and country in one!

Whether you're here for sightseeing, shopping, or simply to experience the vibrant culture of Hong Kong, our location offers the perfect base for your adventures. Here's what makes our neighbourhood special:

Prime Location
Our apartment is situated in one of the most convenient and iconic areas of Hong Kong. You’ll be within walking distance of Mong Kok, Tsim Sha Tsui, and Jordan — all bustling districts filled with endless attractions, shopping, and dining options. Nathan Road, also known as the "Golden Mile," is a lively street lined with shops, neon lights, and cultural landmarks.

Shopping Paradise
Mong Kok: Just a short walk away, Mong Kok is a shopper's dream. Explore the famous Ladies’ Market, Sneakers Street, and trendy Langham Place Mall for everything from affordable finds to luxury items.

Sai Ying Pun is an area in Western District, in the northwestern part of Hong Kong Island, in Hong Kong. It is administratively part of Central and Western District.

In Chinese language (Cantonese dialect regarding the spoken version), Sai (西) means "west" and Ying Pun (營盤) means "camp", especially military camp. It was where the early British military (website hidden) Ying Pun is built on the steeply sloping lower slopes of Victoria Peak and also on the western reclamation. The areas of Shek Tong Tsui and Kennedy Town are located to the west, Sheung Wan and Tai Ping Shan are to the east, and Midlevels is higher on the hill to the south. Victoria Harbour is to the north.

Wan Chai is situated at the western part of Wan Chai District on the northern shore of Hong Kong Island, in Hong Kong. Its other boundaries are Canal Road to the east, Arsenal Street to the west and Bowen Road to the south. The area north of Gloucester Road is often referred to as Wan Chai North.

Wan Chai is one of the busiest commercial areas in Hong Kong with offices of many small and medium-sized companies. Wan Chai North features office towers, parks, hotels and an international conference and exhibition centre. As one of the first areas developed in Hong Kong, the locale is densely populated yet with noticeable residential zones facing urban decay. Arousing considerable public concern, the government has undertaken several urban renewal projects in recent years. There are various landmarks and skyscrapers within the area, most notably the Hong Kong Convention and Exhibition Centre (HKCEC), Central Plaza and Hopewell Centre.

Although it's only a few minutes walk to the bustling Central, Soho, the famous Mid Levels escalator and Lan Kuai Fong, it's a quiet and quaint neighbourhood called Po Hing Fong - the oldest part of Hong Kong - has interesting art galleries, cafes, bars and good restaurants. The beautiful Medical Museum, the famous design hub PMQ and Tai Kwun, which are great destinations, are close by. Getting a cab is easy.

Many restaurants, Cafes, plenty of laundry shops on the block, supermarkets (including international ones), fresh market, gyms, pharmacies... Pretty much everything you need for a pleasant stay. All nearby.

Its a calm street but it can get pretty busy during lunch time on weekdays.

Welcome to Little Taipei. Po Tuck Street offers a slower, more traditional take on life in Hong Kong, where ma-and-pop shops selling cold beer (the original 7Eleven!) and furniture workshops peacefully coexist alongside hipster cafes and global design studios. Also, because it’s a dead-end trafficked primarily by pedestrians, there’s a beautiful neighborliness to the street with special attention paid to the plant array and traditional shrines full of smoking joss sticks on most stoops. Here, in this secret pocket of Hong Kong, you’ll encounter daily moments of quiet surprise and inspiration.

A 10-minute walk in either direction will get you to the fully gentrified areas of Sai Ying Pun to the east or Kennedy Town in the west--both worthy destinations for a night out. Nestled in the picturesque coastal area of Hong Kong Island, Stanley is a charming neighborhood that offers a perfect blend of natural beauty, rich history, and modern attractions. Known for its expansive waterfront and vibrant marketplaces, Stanley is an idyllic retreat for tourists seeking a tranquil escape from the bustling city life.

As you stroll along the scenic Stanley Promenade, you'll be captivated by the panoramic views of the ocean and lush green hills. The iconic Stanley Market is a must-visit, where you can find a diverse array of local handicrafts, souvenirs, and fashionable clothing. For history enthusiasts, the nearby Murray House and Tin Hau Temple provide fascinating insights into Hong Kong's past.

Stanley is also home to a variety of cafes, bars, and restaurants, offering local and international cuisines to suit every palate. Enjoy a leisurely meal by the waterfront or indulge in some local street food while exploring the lively streets.

Sai Ying Pun is an area in Western District, in the northwestern part of Hong Kong Island, in Hong Kong. It is administratively part of Central and Western District.

In Chinese language (Cantonese dialect regarding the spoken version), Sai (西) means "west" and Ying Pun (營盤) means "camp", especially military camp. It was where the early British military (website hidden) Ying Pun is built on the steeply sloping lower slopes of Victoria Peak and also on the western reclamation. The areas of Shek Tong Tsui and Kennedy Town are located to the west, Sheung Wan and Tai Ping Shan are to the east, and Midlevels is higher on the hill to the south. Victoria Harbour is to the north.

Cheung chau is a lovely, relaxing island escape from the Hong Kong bustle. When we get a chance to holiday there, we often find we never want to leave Frank's.  However, we do love a jaunt to Kwun Yam beach. which has a beach bar and chilled atmosphere. Further up the hill from Frank's is a more remote "Italian beach" which we also love. Sea-foodies should head to many of the restaurants on Pak She Praya road. We also like to head to Morocco's for Indian and Thai food. Alternatively, there is a fully fitted kitchen and a gas BBQ, at Franks. The terrace is the spot to relax throughout the day/night. We installed 3 fans, so this applies all year round!

The flat is located in Sheung Wan, Hong Kong’s hipster neighborhood for years. Bordered by Central and Sai Ying Pun, the former waterfront strip used to be a booming business hub that attracted flocks of wealthy Chinese merchants. Once a sleepy area filled with hoi mei shops and antique dealers, Sheung Wan has experienced a renaissance over the last decade or so, with countless restaurants, cafés, and boutiques popping up across the district. The rapid gentrification of Sheung Wan, combined with its historical and cultural landmarks, has made for a unique combination of old and new; third-wave cafés now rub shoulders with traditional Chinese medicine shops, and you can go from flashy restaurants to ancient temples in a mere matter of steps.

Just a stone’s throw away from the ever-bustling Causeway Bay (and often overshadowed by it), Tai Hang offers a rare pocket of respite that’s often hard to find on Hong Kong Island. Home to a funky array of indie cafes, hidden shops, local eateries, and historic landmarks, this charming neighbourhood is an understatedly hip area that we’ll never get tired of visiting. Here are just some of our favourite spots to hit up in Tai Hang, most of which offer delivery and takeaway options too.

What is Tai Hang known for?
Come Mid-Autumn Festival – which usually takes place in late September to early October – locals from around the city gather in Tai Hang for the annual Fire Dragon Dance, one of the most spectacular traditions during the festival. This ancient ritual sees a 67 metre-long dragon (the head alone weighs 48kg) with 72,000 incense sticks burning on its body, being carried through the streets of Tai Hang by hundreds of performers. Jordan is a neighborhood of contrasts, with modern and classic all complementing each other. Look around and observe the traces of time. Along Jordan Road, old buildings and restaurants from the pre-war era still evoke the days of a bygone age. Further along, at the West Kowloon Waterfront Promenade, modern skyscrapers have taken over the skyline, with
the most spectacular of all: the sky-high International Commerce Centre. Jordan is exciting any time of the day. By day, it is alive with crowds jostling along the streets and street vendors competing for attention. By night, illuminating neon signs light up, and Temple Street and the food stalls take over; serving up a dazzling array of goods, tasty treats, street performances,
and fortune tellers.

Gough Street and Kau U Fong are like the dynamic duo of Hong Kong's trendy neighborhoods. Gough Street is a charming pedestrian street lined with a mix of quirky shops, cozy cafes, and mouth-watering eateries. It's the perfect place to wander and discover hidden gems, and the vibe is always bustling and vibrant.

Kau U Fong, on the other hand, is a quieter road that leads up to the Mid-Levels neighborhood. Despite its small size, it packs a punch with its trendy boutiques, stylish restaurants, and chic cafes. The atmosphere is sophisticated and cosmopolitan, and you can't help but feel like you're part of an exclusive club just by strolling through.

Together, Gough Street and Kau U Fong create a harmonious blend of old-world charm and modern sophistication. It's a place where you can indulge your senses, satisfy your cravings, and soak up the energy of one of Hong Kong's most enchanting neighborhoods.

Sheung Wan is a vibrant area in Hong Kong, located between Central and Sai Ying Pun. The site of the original occupation of Hong Kong by the British forces in 1842, Sheung Wan was once lined with shops stocked with Asian antiques, temples, and hole-in-the-wall eateries. Some of this remains, but these days, you will the neighborhood is filled with cafes, chic restaurants, designer shops and more. This unique blend of tradition and modernity gives Sheung Wan its charm.

A mash-up of old and new, Sheun Wan is the only place in Hong Kong where you will find traditional coffin stores, historic temples, and dried seafood stalls next to comtemporary art galleries, chic boutiques, and gourmet restaurants.

Fuk Lo Tsun, located in Kowloon, is a vibrant district that offers a unique cultural and culinary experience. This bustling neighborhood is renowned for its bustling markets, authentic street food, and rich history.

As you wander through the narrow alleyways, you'll encounter a colorful tapestry of shops selling everything from traditional herbs and spices to trendy fashion accessories. Lai Chi Wo is one of the oldest and best-preserved Hakka walled villages in the northeast New Territories. The over 300-year-old rural settlement saw its heyday in the 1950s, when nearly a thousand villagers lived in more than 200 houses and terraces among the surrounding hills. Despite departure of many villagers at start of 1960s, the village was abandoned until the universities, NGOs, charities trust, business corporations, local villagers and community farmers adopt a collaborative model to revitalize the village and was awarded UNESCO’s prestigious 2020 Special Recognition for Sustainable Development award for promoting cultural heritage conservation.

Located in Plover Cove Country Park, Lai Chi Wo is also part of the Hong Kong UNESCO Global Geopark due to its special geological significance as well as natural and cultural richness. Its coastline has the largest population of Coastal Heritiera and White-flowered Derris in Hong Kong and was designated as a Site of Speci

Tsim Sha Tsui (TST) is a vibrant and bustling district in Hong Kong that offers a mix of cultural, shopping, dining, and entertainment experiences. Here are some of the best spots and aspects to explore in Tsim Sha Tsui:

Victoria Harbour: Tsim Sha Tsui offers stunning views of Victoria Harbour, especially during the evening when the Symphony of Lights show illuminates the skyline. The waterfront promenade is a great place for a leisurely stroll and to take in the iconic Hong Kong skyline.

Avenue of Stars: Modeled after the Hollywood Walk of Fame, the Avenue of Stars honors Hong Kong's film industry. Visitors can find handprints of famous celebrities, enjoy the view of the harbor, and catch the nightly light show.

Tsim Sha Tsui Promenade: Take a leisurely walk along the waterfront promenade for breathtaking views of the cityscape and the harbor. It's a popular spot for locals and tourists alike.

Sheung Wan is a vibrant neighborhood with a diverse mixture of hip cafes, shops & restaurants next to local traditional establishments. Everything you’ll need is just a quick walk & public transportation is easily accessible.

There are plenty of food options right at your doorstep, from Western seafood, cafe, Korean fried chicken, to Japanese or Hong Kong-style hotpot.

The building faces an entire culinary street with seafood, coffee shops, Korean fried chickens, and Japanese or Hong Kong hot pots.

Pui O, located on the southern shoreline of Lantau Island, is an old fishing village with a picturesque setting between mountains and a long stretch of open beach. It has become a popular weekend and holiday destination for locals and visitors alike.

The main attraction of Pui O is its family-friendly beach, which spans approximately 700 meters from west to east. Visitors can enjoy various recreational activities and soak up the sun, providing a refreshing escape from the city's hustle and bustle.

Walking between the beach and the main village, you will pass through paddocks where Hong Kong's beloved feral buffalo, also known as cows, can often be spotted. Some of them even make their way to the beach. Along the South Lantau Island Road that cuts through the village, there are a few restaurants to satisfy your hunger.

At the eastern end of Pui O Beach, you can find the historic Tin Hau Temple, which is worth a quick visit for its cultural significance.<

If retail runs through Hong Kong’s arteries, then Causeway Bay is the beating heart that keeps it going. From big-name designer brands piled atop one another in gleaming glass towers to rising stars in street style, fashion feels at home in the district. However, it’s much more than just a shopper’s paradise. Venture beyond the multitude of malls and discover an alluring enclave that’s brimming with character, Hong Kong Island’s largest public park and a rich history tied to its past as a former fishing village.

Named after the cove that it’s now built on top of, Causeway Bay’s erstwhile coastline is today marked by Tung Lo Wan Road, while landmarks including a 19th century Tin Hau temple dedicated to the Goddess of the Sea, the Noon Day Gun and a bronze statue of British monarch Queen Victoria recall the territory’s Chinese and British influences.

- **Tsim Sha Tsui Promenade**: A short MTR ride away, enjoy stunning Victoria Harbour views, the Avenue of Stars, and world-class museums.
